title: WeWork founder to pocket $185m as board backs SoftBank rescue
text:
WeWork's ousted founder Adam Neumann will be paid $185m (£143m) to leave the company after the office space firm accepted a bid by investor SoftBank to provide crucial funding.

The business decided on Tuesday to accept funding from SoftBank that cut its valuation to just $8bn and removed Mr Neumann as chairman.

As part of the deal, he relinquished his voting shares in the firm and his board seat.

Mr Neumann will sell $1bn of stock to SoftBank, be given $500m of credit and paid a $185m consulting fee, The Wall Street Journal reported.

The $10bn (£7.7bn) financing deal offered by Japanese telecoms conglomerate SoftBank will allow the firm to avoid running out of funding next month but handed the investor around 80pc of the business.

A rival debt package offered by JP Morgan was rejected by WeWork’s board.

WeWork's new co-chief executives are planning to lay off at least 2,000 employees. The layoffs have been delayed from earlier this month, however, because the company struggled to afford the severance costs, The Wall Street Journal reported.

The funding from SoftBank marks a major fall from grace for WeWork, once a darling of Silicon Valley and valued at as much as $47bn earlier this year.

The company, which rents out office space, abandoned its high-profile plans to list its shares after investors questioned its large losses, the sustainability of its business model and its governance.

The significant slide in WeWork's valuation has also affected the value of employee options, with the paper wealth of workers dropping following the firm's abandoned float.

JPMorgan's proposed package faced headwinds as it had not underwritten the debt and was seeking banks and other investors to back the deal.

The SoftBank offer reportedly included $5bn in new debt plus the acceleration of an earlier $1.5bn equity injection.

The equity portion of the deal was first negotiated in January based on a $47bn valuation for WeWork but SoftBank renegotiated it at a valuation of just $8bn.

SoftBank, together with its $100bn Vision Fund, already owns about a third of WeWork. It has already put as much as $10.6bn into the company.
